message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor and will increase mercaptopurine toxicity. Dexrazoxane, Mesna, and Amifostine are all cytoprotective agents and do not affect mercaptopurine metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Allopurinol inhibits the metabolism of mercaptopurine, leading to an increased risk of toxicity. Dexrazoxane, Mesna, and Amifostine do not have this effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. 6-mercaptopurine is metabolized by xanthine oxidase, which is inhibited by allopurinol. Therefore, administration of allopurinol would increase the patient's risk for 6-mercaptopurine toxicity. Dexrazoxane is a cardioprotective agent, Mesna is a bladder protectant, and Amifostine is a cytoprotective agent used to reduce the risk of radiation-induced mucositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Allopurinol inhibits the metabolism of 6-mercaptopurine, leading to increased toxicity. Dexrazoxane, Mesna, and Amifostine do not have any known interactions with 6-mercaptopurine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. 6-mercaptopurine is metabolized by xanthine oxidase, and allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor. Therefore, administration of allopurinol would increase the patient's risk for mercaptopurine toxicity. None of the other options affect xanthine oxidase metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only allopurinol is known to increase the risk of mercaptopurine toxicity by inhibiting its metabolism. The other options are not known to interact with mercaptopurine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Allopurinol inhibits the metabolism of mercaptopurine, which can lead to increased toxicity. Dexrazoxane is a cardioprotective agent, Mesna is used for bladder protection, and Amifostine is a radioprotective agent, so they do not affect mercaptopurine metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Allopurinol inhibits the metabolism of 6-mercaptopurine, which can lead to increased toxicity of the drug. None of the other options have interactions with 6-mercaptopurine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The correct answer is (C) Allopurinol as it inhibits the metabolism of mercaptopurine, leading to toxicity. The other options either have no effect on mercaptopurine or can help reduce toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Allopurinol inhibits the metabolism of 6-mercaptopurine, which can lead to increased toxicity. The other options are not known to interact with 6-mercaptopurine metabolism.
